newsitem.title: JAPAN: RTRS-Murdoch launches JSkyB, heralding TV battle.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Murdoch launches JSkyB, heralding TV battle.

text.p: Media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Japan's Softbank Corp formally announced on Tuesday they had set up a broadcasting company to offer multichannel satellite television in Japan.

The launch of Japan Sky Broadcasting Co (JSkyB) sets the stage for a battle for viewers between the Murdoch alliance and rivals including a digital satellite broadcaster owned by Hughes Electronics Corp., part of General Motors Corp.

Murdoch and Softbank President Masayoshi Son told a news conference that JSkyB, capitalised at 20 billion yen ($175 million) and officially set up on Monday, will launch a 12-channel service on a trial basis using the JSAT-3 satellite next April. The number of channels will rise to around 150 the following April.
Softbank, a software and publishing firm, has been aggressively expanding into computer-related and media fields, earning Son the nickname "Asia's Bill Gates".

In a move which could help give JSkyB an edge in the Japanese satellite TV market, the companies also said they would work with a Japanese rival, PerfecTV, to develop a common receiver for both services.
"Such a receiver will allow Japanese viewers to access about 260 channels provided jointly by JSkyB and PerfecTV by April 1998," Son said.
PerfecTV, which started pay services in October, will provide a 100-channel service by next spring. It is owned by a group of Japanese trading companies.
Another prospective rival is Hughes Corp's DirecTV, which plans a 100-channel service in Japan in the autumn of 1997.
Altogether, around 360 channels will be beamed into Japanese homes in early 1998.

The fresh competition from satellite packages offering a wide range of news and entertainment is also expected to energise Japan's terrestrial commercial broadcasters, who, some analysts say, have grown complacent about the standard fare of variety and gameshows.
Son said JSkyB will combine 50 to 60 major programmes including news, music and entertainment, in a low-cost package, while films and sports will be provided separately.
One big question, however, is whether the operators will be able to get terrestrial broadcasters, which feel under threat from satellite operators, to contribute quality programming.

Asked about the difficulty in acquiring such programmes, Murdoch said: "We have received cooperation from Japanese software houses, production companies and some terrestrials. We don't see any difficulty at all."
Industry analysts said both News Corp and Hughes have sought the cooperation of Japan's upmarket public broadcaster NHK.
But NHK, which is sticking to its own analogue-based Muse satellite broadcasting technology, is said to have rejected the idea of cooperation with the newcomers.
